property.value: 5100 W. J.B. Hunt Drive, Suite 602, Rogers, AR 72758

synopsis.value: The Premises consist of approximately 14,642 usable and 17,090 rentable square feet on the 6th floor of the Building at 5100 W. J.B. Hunt Drive, Rogers, AR. The Primary Term is 77 months ending on the last day of the 77th full month, with an option to extend to 90 months upon notice.

keyParameters.value: Usable Area: 14,642 sf; Rentable Area: 17,090 sf; Primary Term: 77 months; Extension Option: up to 90 months; Notice Period for Extension: 14 days (as later restated 21 days); Commencement Date: defined by completion of landlord work and tenant move‑in steps.

narrative.value: As indicated by Exhibit A, the Premises are situated on the 6th floor of the Building located at 5100 W. J.B. Hunt Drive, Suite 6SG, Rogers, Arkansas 72758. The area shall be measured by Core Architects and validated by Nielsen Architects using ANSI/BOMA Z65.1‑1996. The Primary Term shall end on the last day of the seventy‑seventh (77th) full month, with a tenant right to extend to ninety (90) months within fourteen (14) days of the Commencement Date (later restated as twenty‑one (21) days).

synopsis.value: Landlord pays real property taxes; any excess over the Base Year (2016) is passed through to tenants on a pro‑rata basis. Tenant is responsible for taxes on personal property and fixtures.

definition.value: "Taxes" means all real property taxes and special assessments levied against the Premises, Land and improvements.

keyParameters.value: Base Year: Calendar year 2016; Pass‑through Trigger: Taxes exceeding Base Year; Tenant Share: Pro‑rata square footage; Tenant Personal Property Tax Liability: Yes.

narrative.value: Landlord agrees to pay all real property taxes and special assessments that accrue against the Premises. Property taxes incurred in any year that exceed the taxes on the property during the "Base Year" (2016) will be passed through to tenants based on a pro‑rata square footage basis. Tenant shall be liable for all taxes levied on personal property or fixtures placed in the Premises.

synopsis.value: Operating expenses in excess of the Base Year (2016) are passed through to tenants on a pro‑rata basis, with a 5% annual cap on controllable expenses and specific exclusions for capital improvements, casualty, financing costs, etc.

definition.value: "Operating Expenses" means the actual ordinary and reasonable costs incurred by Landlord for ownership, management, maintenance, repair, replacement, restoration or operation of the Real Property, excluding specified items.

keyParameters.value: Base Year: 2016; Pass‑through Trigger: Expenses exceeding Base Year; Tenant Share Formula: Tenant Rentable Sq Ft / Building Total Rentable Sq Ft (226,468); Annual Increase Cap on Controllable Expenses: 5%; Billing: Annual statement within 90 days, Tenant review within 6 months.

billingTimeline.value: Landlord sends an annual statement of Operating Expenses within ninety (90) days after year‑end; Tenant must provide written notice of intent to review within six (6) months of receipt; payment of Additional Rent is due monthly.

formulas.value: Tenant Proportionate Share = (Tenant Rentable Sq Ft ÷ 226,468) × (Operating Expenses – Base Year Expenses).

capitalRules.value: Capital improvements are excluded unless they directly reduce Tenant’s Operating Expenses, in which case they are amortized over useful life per GAAP/ASHRAE.

narrative.value: Operating expenses incurred in any year that exceed the Operating Expenses on the Building for the Base Year (2016) will be passed through to the Building tenants on a pro‑rata basis. Controllable Operating Expenses shall not increase by more than five percent (5%) annually. Landlord shall provide an annual statement and Tenant may review the expenses within ninety (90) days after receipt of the statement.

synopsis.value: Landlord is responsible for structural components, roof, foundation, exterior walls, common areas and building systems; Tenant is responsible for interior maintenance, repairs, and any damage caused by Tenant. Landlord may charge $50 per hour for tenant‑requested maintenance.

narrative.value: Landlord shall make all repairs and replacements to the Building and Common Areas required to keep such areas in good operating condition, except for specific repairs that Tenant must make. Tenant shall maintain the usable Premises in good condition and promptly make necessary repairs. Landlord’s maintenance excludes roof, foundation, exterior walls, structural components, and building systems. Tenant may be charged $50 per hour for Landlord‑provided maintenance personnel when the work is Tenant’s responsibility.

synopsis.value: Tenant may not make alterations without Landlord’s prior written consent, which shall not be unreasonably withheld. Alterations affecting the building structure are prohibited. Tenant must provide drawings and may use Landlord‑approved contractors.

Tenant may install corporate signage per Exhibit E, must comply with laws and building standards, and must remove signage at lease end at its own cost. Additional exterior signage requires Landlord’s prior written consent.

Landlord provides water, temperature control (HVAC), optional janitorial services, standard electrical lighting, elevator service, and 24/7 electronic key access. Tenant may request after‑hours HVAC at additional cost and is responsible for any extra services.

Landlord maintains replacement‑cost insurance on the Building. Tenant maintains workers’ compensation, general liability ($2M property, $4M per occurrence), and fire/extended coverage for Tenant Improvements, naming Landlord as additional insured.

keyParameters.value: Landlord Insurance: Replacement cost; Tenant Liability: $2,000,000 property, $4,000,000 per occurrence; Workers’ Comp: required; Fire/Extended Coverage: required for Tenant Improvements.

synopsis.value: If the Premises are destroyed or damaged such that repairs cannot be completed within 120 days, the Lease terminates and rent is abated. If repairs are completed within 120 days, rent is abated proportionally. Tenant may terminate if damage exceeds 30% of rentable space.

Each party indemnifies the other against claims arising from the other’s negligence, except for the indemnifying party’s own gross negligence or intentional acts. Each party must defend the other in such claims.

Premises shall be used only for Tenant’s business offices and lawful purposes related thereto. Storage of trucks or vehicles requires Landlord’s consent. Tenant must comply with all laws, building covenants, and Rules and Regulations.
Landlord may enter the Premises with twenty‑four (24) hour notice for inspections, repairs, or to show to prospective purchasers; emergency entry without notice is permitted.

Tenant may assign or sublet all or part of the Premises to affiliates or any company with net worth of at least $100,000,000, subject to Landlord’s prior written consent (not unreasonably withheld). If subtenant pays rent above Base Rent, Tenant must remit 50% of the excess to Landlord.
Tenant is entitled to at least 4.5 parking spaces per 1,000 rentable square feet at no charge. No exclusive reserved spaces are provided to Tenant; Landlord reserves six (6) spaces for itself.
If more than 50% of the Premises is taken by eminent domain, the Lease terminates and rent is abated. If less than 50% is taken, rent is reduced proportionally; any compensation goes to Landlord.

If Tenant holds over after lease termination, a month‑to‑month tenancy is created at 150% of the Base Rent plus Operating Expenses and Taxes. If holdover exceeds three (3) months, additional damages may be assessed.
Tenant shall peacefully enjoy the Premises without interference from Landlord, provided Tenant pays all amounts due and complies with covenants.

Events of default include failure to pay Base Rent within five (5) business days after notice, among others. Late charge is 5% of overdue amount. Landlord may pursue remedies including termination, re‑letting, and recovery of damages.
Lease is subordinate to any existing or future mortgages or deeds of trust, subject to a non‑disturbance agreement. Tenant must execute any documents required by mortgagees.
Tenant may not place any lien or encumbrance on the Premises; must promptly notify Landlord of any lien claim.
Tenant may not store or use hazardous materials except for typical office supplies. Spills must be reported; Tenant bears cost of cleanup if caused by Tenant.

Tenant must comply with building Rules and Regulations attached as Exhibit C, including lock control, directory listings, signage restrictions, movement of goods, and prohibited activities such as sleeping quarters, animals, and use of hazardous equipment.
Sage Partners represents Tenant; Pinnacle Realty Group represents Landlord. Separate brokerage agreement to be executed.
Tenant must deliver an estoppel certificate upon Landlord’s request, confirming lease terms, rent status, and absence of defaults.

All notices must be in writing, delivered personally, by certified mail (return receipt requested), or by nationally recognized overnight carrier to the addresses set forth in the Basic Lease Information.
Tenant has a right of first refusal on adjacent space on the 6th floor. Landlord must notify Tenant of any bona‑fide offer; Tenant has ten (10) business days to respond.
Tenant may expand into First Refusal Space under the same rental rate; Landlord shall not relocate Tenant during the term or any renewal periods.

If Landlord fails to cure a default within thirty (30) days after notice, Tenant may terminate the Lease, cure the default and offset costs against rent, or pursue other remedies. Tenant may also cure certain emergencies and offset costs.

executiveSummary.value: This lease, dated May 2015, is between PH Office 2, LLC (Landlord) and Bayer HealthCare LLC (Tenant). The Premises are on the 6th floor of 5100 W.J.B. Hunt Drive, Suite 6SG, Rogers, Arkansas, comprising approximately 17,090 rentable sq ft (14,642 usable sq ft). The Primary Term runs for 77 months, ending on the last day of the 77th full month, with a Tenant‑option to extend to 90 months by giving notice within 21 days of Commencement; two additional five‑year Renewal Terms are available upon 180‑365 day notice. Base rent starts at $24.50 per rsf for year 1, increasing 2 % annually, with rent commencing in the 6th month; a detailed rent schedule is provided. Tenant receives a $72.22 per rsf improvement allowance (increasing to $84.42 per rsf if the term is extended). Early termination is permitted at month 51 with six‑month notice, triggering a termination fee equal to the unamortized improvement allowance plus interest. Parking is allocated at 4.5 spaces per 1,000 rsf at no charge. Landlord is responsible for structural repairs, roof, and common‑area systems; Tenant handles interior maintenance, utilities, and insurance (workers’ comp $2 M, general liability $4 M). The lease includes standard provisions for CAM charges, operating‑expense caps, insurance, indemnities, signage rights, hazardous‑material restrictions, and a right of first refusal on adjacent space.

audit_items.issue_description: Lease Date is shown as "_`--5. 2015" which is garbled and unclear.
audit_items.recommended_action: Verify the correct lease execution date with the parties and amend the document.

audit_items.issue_description: Security Deposit field is marked as "Intentionally Deleted" with no amount specified.
audit_items.recommended_action: Confirm whether a security deposit is required; if so, insert the amount and terms.

audit_items.issue_description: Exhibit D (Memorandum of Acceptance of Delivery) lacks critical data: Possession Date, rentable square footage, Proportionate Share, and Early Termination dates are blank.
audit_items.affected_clause: Exhibit D – Memorandum of Acceptance of Delivery
audit_items.recommended_action: Obtain and fill in the missing values before execution; ensure they are reflected in the lease.

audit_items.issue_description: Exhibit A (Premises description) references area on Exhibit A but the actual square footage details are only partially repeated; no map or floor plan attached.
audit_items.recommended_action: Attach the complete floor plan and verify the usable and rentable square footage.

audit_items.issue_description: Basic Lease Information states it controls over any conflict, yet later sections (e.g., Rent Commencement and Base Rent) contain provisions that could contradict the Basic Lease Information.
audit_items.affected_clause: Conflict resolution clause (Basic Lease Information vs. Lease provisions)
audit_items.recommended_action: Review all sections for inconsistencies; explicitly reconcile any contradictory terms.

audit_items.issue_description: Rent Commencement Date is defined by a multi‑step condition involving landlord’s completion, notice, tenant’s installation period, and certificate of occupancy; the sequence and timing are vague.
audit_items.recommended_action: Clarify each trigger event, assign specific dates or deadlines, and define what constitutes “substantial completion.”

audit_items.issue_description: "Landlord shall provide notice to Tenant that construction has been completed" – no method or timeframe for notice is defined.
audit_items.recommended_action: Specify notice method (e.g., certified mail) and required response time.

audit_items.issue_description: Landlord’s “reasonable and good‑faith determination of the annual Base Rent payable” for Renewal Terms is subjective.
audit_items.recommended_action: Define objective criteria or a formula for rent determination; consider third‑party appraisal trigger.

audit_items.issue_description: Tenant Improvement Allowance amount changes if the Primary Term is extended to 90 months, but the calculation for the increased allowance ($84.42 per RSF) is not tied to a clear schedule or cap.
audit_items.recommended_action: Provide a detailed amortization schedule and cap on total allowance to prevent unexpected cost overruns.

audit_items.issue_description: Operating Expense cap of 5% annually applies only to “controllable” expenses, but the definition of controllable is vague and may be interpreted broadly.
audit_items.recommended_action: Define which expense categories are considered controllable and include audit rights for verification.

audit_items.issue_description: Termination Fee calculation involves reimbursement of unamortized Improvement Allowance and Broker’s commission with a 7% annual interest rate, but the exact formula and timing are not detailed.
audit_items.recommended_action: Insert a precise formula, include a schedule for interest accrual, and specify the date of calculation.

audit_items.issue_description: Option to extend Primary Term to 90 months must be exercised within 14 days of Commencement Date (Section 3) but later Section 5 requires 21 days notice; contradictory notice periods.
audit_items.recommended_action: Standardize the notice period for extension throughout the lease.

audit_items.issue_description: Base Rent schedule table shows $0.00 for months 1‑5, yet the lease states rent commences on the first day of the sixth full month; however, earlier text mentions rent commencement could be earlier if rent commencement date falls on a non‑first day of month.
audit_items.recommended_action: Reconcile the rent commencement provisions with the rent schedule; clarify prorated rent rules.

audit_items.issue_description: Landlord’s “reasonable efforts” to secure SNDA and financing are mentioned without measurable standards.
audit_items.recommended_action: Add specific milestones or deadlines for these efforts.

audit_items.issue_description: First Right of Refusal (Section 30) requires Tenant to provide notice within 10 business days, but the lease also states 10 business days for landlord’s response to consent; potential timing conflict.
audit_items.recommended_action: Clarify the sequence and exact deadlines for both parties.

audit_items.issue_description: Exhibit C (Rules and Regulations) references rules but the full list is not attached; only excerpts are present.
audit_items.recommended_action: Attach the complete Rules and Regulations document.

audit_items.issue_description: Landlord’s “reasonable and good‑faith determination” of additional rent for operating expense increases is not quantified.
audit_items.recommended_action: Specify the estimation methodology or require third‑party verification.

audit_items.issue_description: Late charge of 5% for overdue payments plus an additional 5% after notice creates potentially punitive fees without a cap.
audit_items.recommended_action: Introduce a maximum cumulative late fee or a grace period.

audit_items.issue_description: Section 5 (Landlord’s Repairs) states landlord is responsible for roof, foundation, structural walls, etc., while Section 11 (Landlord’s Repairs and Maintenance) lists many items landlord maintains but also says tenant must repair damage caused by tenant; potential overlap on who repairs structural components after damage.
audit_items.recommended_action: Clarify responsibility for repair of structural components after damage caused by tenant or third parties.

audit_items.issue_description: Clause allowing Tenant to terminate early at end of 51st month requires 6 months notice, but later termination provisions (Section 7) reference termination fees and rent abatement without linking to this early termination right.
audit_items.recommended_action: Integrate early termination notice period with termination fee calculations.

audit_items.issue_description: "Landlord shall have the right to enter the Premises at any time without notice in case of emergency" – definition of emergency is not defined.
audit_items.recommended_action: Define what constitutes an emergency to avoid abuse.

audit_items.issue_description: Broker’s commission is mentioned as part of termination fee but the commission amount is not disclosed.
audit_items.recommended_action: Specify the broker commission percentage or amount.

audit_items.issue_description: Exhibit B (Tenant Improvements) is noted as "To be added upon approval of Tenant's Plans" – no details on scope, schedule, or cost.
audit_items.recommended_action: Attach the finalized Tenant Improvement plans and schedule.

audit_items.issue_description: Clause stating Tenant shall not "overload floors" and must obtain Landlord’s prior written consent for size/weight of equipment, without defining overload thresholds.
audit_items.recommended_action: Provide quantitative load limits or reference engineering standards.

audit_items.issue_description: Section 33 (Landlord Default / Right of Offset) states Landlord shall not have personal liability, yet earlier sections impose indemnification obligations on Landlord for certain damages.
audit_items.recommended_action: Reconcile indemnification language with liability limitation.

audit_items.issue_description: Force Majeure clause lists many events but does not specify how rent abatement is calculated during such events.
audit_items.recommended_action: Add a formula or method for rent abatement during force majeure periods.

audit_items.issue_description: "Landlord shall have reasonable efforts to secure a commercially reasonable SNDA" – no metric for reasonableness.
audit_items.recommended_action: Define acceptable timelines and criteria for SNDA execution.

audit_items.issue_description: Tenant’s obligation to pay 50% of any rent received from subtenant that exceeds Base Rent, without a cap, could lead to unpredictable costs.
audit_items.recommended_action: Set a maximum percentage or dollar cap on the overage payment.

audit_items.issue_description: Exhibit D’s Proportionate Share percentage is blank, preventing calculation of tenant’s share of operating expenses and taxes.
audit_items.recommended_action: Calculate and insert the correct proportionate share based on rentable square footage.

audit_items.issue_description: "Landlord shall have the right to waive any one or more of these Rules and Regulations for the benefit of any particular tenant" – no criteria for waiver.
audit_items.recommended_action: Establish written criteria and approval process for any waiver.

audit_items.issue_description: Section 31 (Use) prohibits smoking within 25 feet of the building, while Section 13 (Insurance) requires Tenant not to use the premises for hazardous materials; overlapping safety provisions could cause enforcement confusion.
audit_items.recommended_action: Consolidate safety and use restrictions into a single, clear provision.
